intro: Corydalis anthocrene, commonly known as the yellow corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of central and southern Europe. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, clustered flowers that range from yellow to orange in color. The plant typically grows to a height of about 10 to 30 centimeters and features slender, hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its bloom period occurs in late spring to early summer, and it thrives in well-drained, rocky or sandy soils. Corydalis anthocrene is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a wildflower in naturalized settings.
